lines.text: Dexter, you weren't with me tonight.
Huh?
Well, there's no point in having Daddy tear you into little pieces. You know his temper.
What are you going to tell him?
Oh, I'll think of something. Just remember, no matter what, you weren't with me tonight.
I can't do it. I can't let you take the rap.
Oh, I'll figure out a story.
When?
Oh, I don't know. Give me a minute to think! Oh, my mind's an absolute blank.
If it isn't a blank now, it will be when your old man gets through with you.
Dexter! Not when he gets through, before he starts.
Huh?
My mind's a blank. I can't remember anything. I've got amnesia, like in the movie.
It might work.
Oh, it's gotta work. But Dexter, you must remember, no matter what happens, no matter what I say or do, you weren't with me tonight!
I weren't with you tonight.
Wish me luck.
Well, um, well, it's all very silly, but the fact is that my daughter has written a - a sort of diary.
Indeed? Well, I'm confident that it reflects her girlish charms.
Well, um, this diary is, um ...
You are talking, I take it about that volume that your husband is clutching in his clammy hands?
Well, it's all quite ridiculous, and I'm sure you'll be the first to - Go ahead, Harry. Please read some of it to Mr. Marquis, and then he'll realize how crazy the whole thing is.

[Reading]
"Not all women know really great love. And so few can save the man they love from himself."
[clears his throat]
Doesn't read very fluently, does he?
"Kenny-boy is so sweet. I'm lucky I found Kenny-boy in time." Kenny-boy is you!
Really?
That's from my daughter's diary.
Silly, isn't it?
No, I like it.
It's just schoolgirl romantic nonsense! But, there are reasons why we couldn't question Corliss.
Naturally, after your contemptible invasion of the privacy of her diary.
It's none of your business what I do.
My name is mentioned.
I'll burn every page. Only a fool would think there was any truth to this.
Every single word of it is true.

[Addressing the court]
Seldom in my long career as an attorney have I ever encountered a man who can claim no virtue. But I say to you, you have such a man in your courtroom today. Cold-blooded and ruthless, unmoved by the pain he has caused, Kenneth Marquis smugly sits there gloating. And a poor, loyal, trusting girl suffers. A girl, I say, and yet, she is little more than a child, innocent, and unworldly. Kenneth Marquis treated her like dirt, your honor. And from the moment they were married, yes, even on her bridal night, insults and injuries were heaped upon her.

[to his attorney]
Included in that heap was a 50 foot schooner and a string of pearls. To say nothing of a blond mink, a silver blue mink, and a rainbow mink. Bless her furry little heart. Much as I dislike that poisonous wench, I'm beginning to dislike that attorney of hers even more, if possible.
Daddy, I've just got to have a dollar and a half.
I told you to wait outside.
Rather than witness your churlish behavior, I should be most happy to advance or let's say donate the money myself.
That's very sweet of you.
Don't take that money!
Your poor father's ungraciousness stems partly from a natural tendency to be stuffy, and an unnatural reluctance to part with his holding money.
Kenneth, take it easy.
Oh, you don't know my daddy at all. He's really very -
Don't speak to that man!
Daddy, about my dollar and a half -
Archer, if we could get back to the business at hand -

[to Corliss]
I'll talk to you outside. Now. Alone.
If I were in your position, I should be completely underwhelmed.
It's been awfully nice meeting you, Mr. Marquis.
Oh, and if the indignity of taking money from Daddy Dear ever becomes too great to bear, don't hesitate to call on me.
Stop needling Archer, or we'll never get a settlement.
You know, I'm seriously considering dedicating my entire life to the needling of Harry P. Archer. Nothing gives me greater pleasure.
I wondered who rang. Oh, that's nice. Who sent it? Uncle George? Mmm. Good.
Kenneth Marquis!
Kenneth - Let me see that!
[Reading tag]
"May this brighten a youth blighted by parental stupidity and miserlyness. Kenneth Marquis." He did that to annoy me. I'll - I'll throw it out!
Oh, Daddy, you can't!
What's wrong?
That - that pinhead, that lowdown, shockworn Casanova Marquis sent Corliss this box of candy!
Daddy says I can't keep it!
Why Harry, why on earth - Kenneth Marquis? Sending candy to Corliss?
Well, you see Mom -
Corliss had nothing to do with it. He's trying to irritate me by showing me up as a cheapskate.
Well, if Miss Corliss had nothing to do with Mr. Marquis, I don't think it would hurt if she ate the candy.
Look, Mom.
Well, anyway, you can't return it with a piece missing.
Oh, Daddy ate that piece.

[Holding a paper announcing his daughter's engagement to Kenneth Marquis]
Did you see this?
I gave out the story.
Did you - ?
Dad, do I take it that you're not altogether pleased?
Why you -
Congratulations, Archer.
Shut up! I'm going to sue your client -
Oh, Dad, I hope Corliss hasn't inherited your bad temper.
What do you mean by this? Answer me! Answer me.
Do you think I was just trifling with a good woman's love?
I wouldn't let Corliss marry you if - if - if - Call up and issue a denial!
Oh no! All denials will be issued by you. We don't want any breach of promise suits.
I'll have a retraction in the paper by - by - by six o'clock, and maybe earlier if I can get them to print a special edition.
Very well, if your daughter's happiness is so unimportant to you, I will try to bear up manfully.
I guess you know about this article in Glimpse. It just came out today. It's a good picture of you, Corliss.
I'm the father of a girl with a national reputation like Catherine the Great.
Hi, Mr. Archer.
Oh ...
This is tomorrow.
I'll make a note of that fact on my calender.
Do you mind, Dexter, we're awfully busy.
But you promised to talk to me about the blackmail today.
At this moment there is nothing in the world I'd be willing to talk to you about. Now get out!
Holy cow!
If I were Archer, I'd be after you with a shotgun!
Well, a shotgun is customary only in cases where the bridegroom is unwilling. I, on the other hand, am panting with eagerness. Ha. Ha. Ha.
Humph! One slip up and you're the formerly wealthy Mr. Marquis. Aside from Archer, your stockholders won't stand for any more escapades in court.

[phone buzzes]
Yeah? It's Pop. Probably wants another retraction. Hello, Pop. This is Sonny. Oh! Language! I don't know why you're so upset. Everyone knows that young love is, um, impetuous. Oh, please, Daddy Dear. I seem to notice a certain beligerence in your tone. You what? Consent? What? When? Oh, I see. You do? Oh, you don't. You will? Who? Me? Oh.
[hangs up phone]
I'm about to become a husband.
The groom usually has a father or brother stand up with him. Have you any close relatives who might - ?
One of my ex-wives?

Hardly. Let's get on with it. Louise. Uh, dearly beloved, we are gathered, um, so on and so on. To join together this man and this woman, and so on and so on. Well, there's no use going any further with this part of the rehearsal.
Certainly not on my behalf. I know it by heart.

[to Mr. Archer]
Cheer up, old fellow. If providence should bless you with a grandson, we'll call the little stinker Harry P. Marquis.
Perhaps you could explain to me how I happened to find myself in this position?
Because you belatedly came to what little sense you have. Try and get out of it now, and you have a breach of promise suit, a stockholder suit, and why go on with the list?
Well, I certainly shan't number it among the gayer weddings to which I have participated. Maybe I'm spoiled, but the others were much more fun!
I don't know, I thought the blood in your father-in-law's eye lent a nice touch of festive color.
Uncle George? Have you any hobbies? I mean, do you collect things, and things?
I have a large collection of antique rocks. Every one of which I would like to throw at you!
